item.title: Thinking Outside the Box You Built Yourself
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1016" align="alignright" width="262" caption="Steve Keys on Flickr"][/caption]

“There are people who put their dreams in a little box and say, "Yes, I've got dreams, of course I've got dreams." Then they put the box away and bring it out once in awhile to look in it, and yep, they're still there.” -Emma Bombeck

Since I was a little kid, I was taught that I could not support myself doing something fun that I loved. I would have to find a job that tediously 'contributed' to society in order to make enough money so I'd have the resources to spend my free time engaged in enjoyable 'hobbies'. Life would always be a trade off between doing what you had to, based on what someone else deemed was a valuable use of your time, and doing what you wanted.

Recently, I've begun to question the assumption that doing something you enjoy is a poor way to make money. Of course, if you're really lucky, you'll end up in a job you love, so money-making will be bearable, but the emphasis was on fitting yourself into a job, rather than the other way around.
